advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote>In June 1983, IBM was still seeking independant programmers.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666" The envelope please.<br> There's an acceptance letter inside. And a check that could have your name on it. (If we select your program, that is.)<br> But remember. We pick our winners carefully... </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Soichiro Oga / <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Old PC leaflets museum</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the time of this advert (September 1980), Heathkit introduced a music synthetiser board, a speech lab, a color graphic board, a color monitor and Microsoft BASIC and FORTRAN languages. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOG (1992)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Evolutiv system : Casio's answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST +4 SALES, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2D ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Z-2D 1977 price list:<br><br> - Kit version with 1 F.D. drive: <b>$1495</b><br> - Assembled version: <b>$2095</b><br> - Additional F.D. drive: <b>$495</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Orion Young for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably one of the first adverts for the Osborne 1.<br> Personal Computing, February 1982.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The facts speak for themselves. The QUAY 500 SERIES offers more for the money than North Star Horizon computers...<br><br> ...The bottom line is simple. There is a new star in the computer field. The 500 SERIES by Quay. It outshines all of the competition.<br><br></font> A little pretentious tone!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.colors: Monochrome. White green or orange phosphor
computer.description:
The Cifer 2683 was the stand-alone version of a large range of dumb terminals released in the UK by the Cifer Systems Limited Company.
The 2683 was actually a Z80 based 2632 terminal to which a second Z80 card has been added, providing 64 KB of user RAM and a floppy-disk controller. The machine was used as a Z80 software development or general purpose CP/M system. A ROM/EPROM card allowed to develop and run custom programs.
A 300 x 1024 pixel graphics board was also available, including a third Z80A CPU and providing Tektronix 4010 compatibility.
A 2684 was also released, with same features as the 2683 but including a built-in 5.25" floppy-disk drives instead of an external unit. _______________________
computer.keyboard: 100 key Typewriter type with 20 function key and numeric keypad
computer.media: Dual DS DD 48 TPI floppy-disk unit
computer.ports: Parallel printer (2), serial lines (2), FDD unit, Composite video
computer.rom: Depends on system configuration, up to 24 KB

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Complete system along with its dual FDD unit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>20 function keys allow a direct access to the most common terminal editing functions.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Terminal configuration dip switches<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Jack for an external composite monitor<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Floppy-disk unit connector <br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Serial line connector of the terminal section<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Parallel printer connector of the terminal section<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Serial line connector of the computer section<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Parallel printer connector of the computer section. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The electronics was comprised of three cards:<br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> The terminal card in charge of video, keyboard and communication management,<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> The CPU card which holds the second Z80 processor, 64 to 256 KB of RAM, the FDD controller, additional serial and parallel ports,<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> A piggy-back ROM/EPROM card holding custom programs.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SYSTEM CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each card uses its own Z80 processor, ROM, RAM and I/O chips.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CIFER RANGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The range of Cifer stand-alone computers in early 1982</blockquote>

computer.text: 80 characters x 25 lines - 8x12 dot char. format
